text: well i'm joined by professor alexandra
antonelli who is director of science at
kew gardens although as you see he joins
us clearly from the conference itself
joins me this afternoon from glasgow
professor thanks so much for your time
uh we're all interested to know of
course how encouraged or otherwise you
are by what you are hearing around the
issue of deforestation
thank you good afternoon jane
i think it's absolutely exciting to see
the commitment from the global leaders
now to absolutely halt deforestation
this is going to lead to huge benefits
to climate to people
and of course to biodiversity but i
think many people are still skeptical
i've just been talking to some
indigenous communities here and they say
that the decisions are made here today
in glasgow you know they're not really
going to reach all the way to the ground
in the amazon so i shared the sympathy
of some of the frustration and
skepticism that many people have shown
here in this in the news and i really
hurt to see those images because i grew
up seeing those images myself and i've
seen so much of that forest being lost
and i really hope this is going to be
the end of that
and if that forest or or cutting down
that forest is someone's livelihood if
that's how they feed their family
surely each government has to have very
strong measures in place not only to
prevent it but to provide those people
with with alternative incomes and that's
the challenge i guess part of it
it is true and that's the the really
critical part of this pledge now because
it's tightly associated to an economic
financial package which will allow those
people to to receive
compensation for not cutting down the
forest and that's an opportunity cost
for them because of course they could be
cultivating soybeans or they could be
growing beef and in this case we are
paying them for not cutting down the
rainforest and for restoring a lot of
what the forest that has been cut down
already so we absolutely need to to
understand and really listen to the
people who are going to be directly
affected by this in many cases it is as
we just saw here smallholder farmers but
perhaps even more commonly it's actually
small it's actually quite large soybean
plantations and that those are not
really bringing any benefits to the
local communities in the indigenous
areas of the amazon
right so uh i mean that's a well i mean
that's that's a fairly depressing
thought and yet you are in glasgow where
lots and lots of countries including
brazil have signed up to this so are
there targets are there mechanisms that
somehow despite what you're explaining
governments will will have to try to see
this through
yes we we are really waiting to see
those details and i think uh in the
meetings i've had here with ministers
some presidents like indigenous
communities there is still a sense of
hope i think everyone who's here now
over this the next few days are
absolutely committed to to making a real
change
the question is how much of that those
words and those commitments are going to
translate into real world action and
change because we've failed before we've
set some really ambitious targets for
both the protection of nature and for
climate and that hasn't worked out so i
think we need to really understand what
our details that our leaders are going
to provide us with and that and just
after that we'll be able to judge
whether or not this is a reasonable uh
step change in what we need to see now
right and like so much of what is being

it's
some of the a lot of these topics it's
it's no good if just a certain number of

yes it's it's a really global asset
we're talking about nature and about the

to humanity and to climate this is
something that we need to provide the

the actions that are taken in brazil for
instance are going to complement those
that are taken in colombia and other
countries around the amazon and it's the
same in other tropical regions we need
to tackle this
together and that's where i
remain optimistic that this meeting is
going to lead to those plans and actions
which will have these long-term benefits
and working together in collaboration
and with the financial models sustaining
those plans as well right interesting so
you so you have some optimism i can i
can see a glimmer there but clearly

i do i i do remain optimistic i mean we
don't have any choice we need to get to
get this right now and the people meet
they are generally interested and really

differently how is this going to
actually translate into positive action
we need to see the results we need to

the next
leader is taking over we need to start
